botanical_details.potentially_harmful: All parts, particularly the seeds, may cause severe discomfort if ingested. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling
botanical_details.genus: Lupinus can be annuals, perennials or shrubs, with palmate leaves and showy terminal racemes of pea-like flowers

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow in moderately fertile, light and well-drained soil in full sun or light, dappled shade
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate from basal softwood cuttings in mid spring. As this plant is protected by Plant Breeders' Rights, any propagation should be for personal rather than commercial use
how_to_grow.pruning: Deadhead to encourage a second flush of flowers. As lupins can be short-lived for perennials, some may be left to seed as replacements, though plants grown from seed may be variable
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to lupin aphid, slugs and snails
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to powdery mildews, lupin anthracnose and virus diseases, and to fungal and bacterial rot particularly in damp conditions
